newsitem.title: UK: BP, CAPC to build Indonesian polybutene plant.
newsitem.headline: BP, CAPC to build Indonesian polybutene plant.

text.p: British Petroleum (BP) and PT Chandri Asri Petrochemical Corporation (CAPC) are to build South East Asia's first polybutenes plant in West Java, BP said.
Both companies, who are 50:50 partners in the project, hope to complete final agreement and issue tenders for design and construction within the next few months.
The new plant, which will be build within the CAPC complex at the Cilegon, is envisaged to come on-stream by late 1999.
It will initially produce up to 45,000 tonnes of polybutenes each year in a range of grades, BP said.
The plant's design would, however, make it possible to gradually raise output to 100,00 per year, the oil company added.
Polybutenes are used in the production of lubricating oil and fuel additives, two-stroke oils as well as adhesives and sealants.
"We aim to be the market leader in polybutenes in Asia," Jim Hay, chemicals developments director of BP Indonesia, said in a statement.
